BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls avalanche prone wind slabs formed. Many large natural avalanches are possible. The new snow and wind slabs of the last two days can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects and generally above the tree line. The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes.
The new snow is lying on a crust on sunny slopes. This snow is lying on soft layers on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In its middle, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls avalanche prone wind slabs formed. Many large natural avalanches are possible. The new snow and wind slabs of the last two days can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects and generally above the tree line. As a consequence of the strong westerly wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses. The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes. In addition further wind slabs will form as the day progresses.
The new snow is lying on a crust on sunny slopes. This snow is lying on soft layers on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In its middle, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls avalanche prone wind slabs formed. Some large natural avalanches are possible. The new snow and wind slabs of the last two days can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line. As a consequence of the strong westerly wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses. The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes. In addition further wind slabs will form as the day progresses.
The new snow is lying on a crust on sunny slopes. This snow is lying on soft layers on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In its middle, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and very particularly the wind slabs represent the main danger. These are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The southeasterly wind has transported the new snow. The mostly small wind slabs of Wednesday will be covered with new snow and therefore barely recognisable.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate wind from southwesterly directions, wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. They can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is slightly greater.

Afternoon: As a consequence of the solar radiation, the likelihood of dry and moist avalanches being released will increase, in particular on very steep sunny slopes, and on wind-loaded slopes. In particular here the avalanches can reach medium size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and up to 30 cm in some localities, fell on Wednesday above approximately 2000 m, in particular along the border with Switzerland.
Thursday: 10 to 20 cm of snow will fall until the afternoon above approximately 1500 m.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow and in particular the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible, in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In addition medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible.
In addition there is a danger of natural moist avalanches, in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2200 m, as well as at the base of rock walls.
Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Wednesday above approximately 1500 m. The wind was strong to storm force at times. In places that are protected from the wind sometimes large wind slabs formed. These are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects above the tree line.
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Thursday above approximately 1500 m.
The wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Some snow will fall on Friday in some localities. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall must be evaluated with care and prudence at intermediate and high altitudes. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind.
The rain will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur.
Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects. The weather report and anticipated change in the avalanche danger are uncertain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind will be strong over a wide area. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. Individual weak layers exist in the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Significant warming. Light precipitation. The wind will be strong. Over a wide area the wind slabs will increase in size additionally.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Small and medium-sized avalanches are possible. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 1800 m. The wind was strong to storm force at times. In places that are protected from the wind wind slabs formed. These are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects above the tree line.
5 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Thursday above approximately 1000 m.
The wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. New snow and wind slabs require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls sometimes large wind slabs formed. Some medium-sized to large natural avalanches are possible. The new snow and wind slabs of the last two days can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line. As a consequence of the strong westerly wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses. The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 10 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes. In addition further wind slabs will form as the day progresses. The new snow is lying on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects. In its middle, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The wind slabs are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The southeasterly wind has transported some snow. The mostly small wind slabs of Wednesday will be covered with new snow and therefore barely recognisable.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate wind from southwesterly directions, wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. They can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects. At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.

Afternoon: As a consequence of the solar radiation, the likelihood of dry and moist avalanches being released will increase on very steep sunny slopes. In the typical avalanche paths in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanches can in isolated cases reach medium size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, fell on Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. This applies in particular along the border with Switzerland.
Thursday: 5 to 10 cm of snow, and up to 20 cm in some localities, will fall until the afternoon above approximately 1500 m.
The new snow is bonding only slowly with the old snowpack.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically. In addition an increasing number of medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind, further wind slabs will form. These can be released easily by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep west, north and east facing slopes. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible especially in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. This applies in particular on very steep shady slopes adjacent to ridgelines at elevated altitudes.

More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones, in the event of prolonged bright spells especially.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Backcountry touring calls for experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, fell on Wednesday. Up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Thursday.
The wind will be strong to storm force. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of warming during the day moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically. In addition an increasing number of medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind, further wind slabs will form. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.
Medium-sized natural avalanches are possible especially in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. This applies in particular on very steep shady slopes adjacent to ridgelines at elevated altitudes.

More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones, in the event of prolonged bright spells especially.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Backcountry touring calls for experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Wednesday. Up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Thursday.
The wind will be strong to storm force. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of warming during the day moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on west to north to east facing aspects. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected, but they will be mostly small.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow fell on Wednesday. In some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall on Thursday. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of warming during the day moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1900 m. In gullies and bowls a sometimes precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. As a consequence of the precipitation, the likelihood of wet snow slides and avalanches being released will increase.
